{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3549240,"name":"","username":"Kully","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kully/{size}/264955_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T13:45:04.605Z","cooked":"

seen some struggle for teams to auto align to the reef so I wanted to create a tutorial of how to do it.

before I begin a I will point out a few things:
I will show the simplest way to auto align to the reef this is not the most optimized way to do it but it works really good when tuned well defiantly faster than 99% of drivers.

also I will talk about the vision processor side a bit but will focus more on the robot code side.

ok first of all to start you will need a way to 3d track april tags.
the 2 easiest way to this right now are limelight and PhotonVision.
both options are good limelight is easier to set up and use so i would recommend it to new teams and teams who want to mess with it less, but limelight‚Äôs are more expansive than running photon so you can decide for your own if its worth it.
this tutorial will use limelight but can be adapted to PhotonVision pretty easily.

for this kind of auto aligning you need to put your camera on the robot in a place it can see the tag both from a far but also when you are very close to it, if needed you can try doing things like putting the camera high looking down or low looking up.

*it is not recommended putting the camera exactly at the height of the tag so go a bit bellow or above.

‚Äé
‚Äé
ok now lets begin for real

setting up the limelight

enable 3d tracking
in the limelight web interface you need to set your pipeline to april tags than go the ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù tab and set the ‚ÄúFull 3D Targeting‚Äù option to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù

image918√ó510 81.1 KB

in here you also need to set your Visualizer setup

I will use ‚ÄúRobot pose in Target Space‚Äù this means the data in the visualizer bellow will be from the pov of the april tag as of it is sable at a fixed point and the robot it moving relative to it.

in the standard tab set the sort mode to closest

image1920√ó1115 64.1 KB

!!NOTICE you also need to tune your camera Exposure and gain I will not explain here how but you can check this doc

‚Äé

code setup and some tuning

you are now done setting up your camera lets move to the robot code.

start by downloading limelight helper class from this link in limelight‚Äôs github and adding it to your code

after you did that create a new command for the auto aligning and now we will see how the aligning itself is done. check the full command is in here full command

!!make sure your drive function is robot relative!!!

what do you need to change to make this command work for you robot

short answer: all the constants

long answer:

image1118√ó195 11.7 KB

the tolerance: this is how much error we are allowing. the smaller the value the more accurate we want to be but the harder it is to tune. I recommend putting this value a bit smaller than how much the robot needs to be aligned.
don‚Äôt make this value too large as than the aligning will stop to early and the robot won‚Äôt be aligned and don‚Äôt make it too small as than it will be really hard to tune, and also d you really need to be accurate to the mm or maybe 5 or 10 mm would be close enough

the setpoints: put your robot on the field where you want it to be at the end of the aligning (where it is when it scores)

then open the limelight web interface and go to the advanced tab and get the robot position from there

make sure you set the view to ‚ÄúRobot pose in Target Space‚Äù

set each setpoint to its relative value in the web interface

x stepoint = TX
y setpoint = TZ*
rot setpoint = RY

*if your camera isn‚Äôt centered with your scoring system you would need to have 2 different values for the right and left reef pipes. if it is centered you can just use the same value but but negative (-Constants.Y_SETPOINT_REEF_ALIGNMENT)

‚Äé

image798√ó149 9.55 KB

DONT_SEE_TAG_WAIT_TIME - how long that we don‚Äôt see the tag before we stop the command

POSE_VALIDATION_TIME - how long we need to be aligned before we finish the command.
too small of a value might make the robot miss if the pid isn‚Äôt perfect and you ahve overshoot, too long just waste time.

recommend putting this at a high value when tuning to make sure the pid is good and there isnt any overshoot and lower it later.

‚Äé

now the most important thing
the pid values this need to be changed by testing and tuning (there a lot of places and threads to learn how to tune) run the command see how it goes and change the values accordingly

image987√ó96 14.2 KB

‚Äé

‚Äé

more in depth explanation of how the code works

what are all of this??

xController - a pid controller that will do the aligning in the x direction
yController - a pid controller that will do the aligning in the y direction
rotController - a pid controller that will do the aligning of the robots rotation

isRightScore - each side of the reef has two scoring pipes this boolean is used to choose if you want to go to the right pipe if it is true or the left pipe if its false

dontSeeTagTimer - this timer counts the time since we last saw the tag we align to and if we haven‚Äôt seen for for some time it automatically stops the command

stopTimer - if the pid is not perfect we might overshot and miss the target this timer is used so that the robot waits a bit when its aligned to make sure it stopped and is truly aligned

tagID - the ID of the tag we align to. *its the first tag saw when we started aligning
‚Äé

builder
setting the pid constants and saving the isRightScore

image1007√ó209 18.4 KB

initialize

image1133√ó496 29.6 KB

creating the timers and starting them

setting the setpoints and tolerance for the pid controllers
setpoint - the target we want to align to
tolerance - what is our acceptable error

getting the id of the tag we align to

‚Äé
execute

image1115√ó563 33.5 KB

the if is checking if we see a target and if the target has the id we are aligning to

we reset the dontSeeTagTimer because we saw a tag

we get the pose of the robot relative to the tag as an array and put in the variable positions

we use the pid to calculate the speed we want the robot to drive at giving it the distance from the tag and it giving us what speeds to drive the robot

drive - setting the speeds for the robot to drive at
!!!NOTICE the drive has to be robot relative and not field relative

‚ÄúyController.getError() < Constants.Y_TOLERANCE_REEF_ALIGNMENT ? xSpeed : 0‚Äù - this line in the drive code is used to make sure we are aligned in the y direction before we start alignin in the x direction
if you want both alignment to happen at the same time replace this with xSpeed


this checks if we are aligned and if not it reset the stop timer

isFinished

image811√ó145 9.54 KB

check if we either didn‚Äôt see a tag in some time or we are aligned and if so stops the command

You should always put your exposure to the minimum or at least keep it to the default 200. Right now as your exposure is 3300 so your limelight will take each frame in 3300 .01ms intervals so each picture will take 33ms to be taken.

Also you should take a look at what the original poster showed in his ‚Äúsetting up the limelight‚Äù explanation

Ok - we see this flicker too. And we suspect we know what‚Äôs going on.

Take your robot to a different overhead lighting source. I believe you will find the flickering suddenly changes or disappears.

It appears that this flickering is an aliasing of the overhead light refresh rate in our location. We did a thought experiment - the 40 hz is about 2/3 of the 60hz AC provided to light fixtures. Sure enough, our flicker acted about the way we‚Äôd expect if there was aliasing going on.

Then, we changed to a much higher resolution to verify it.

You can often see this phenomenon in car lights through dash cams - the LED‚Äôs flicker at a rate fast enough that they look continuous to the eye, but when they sync up with the dash cam you can get some interesting effects.

Google AI explanation:
LED light flicker in dashcam footage is often due to a mismatch between the frequency of the LED lights and the dashcam‚Äôs camera‚Äôs frame rate and shutter speed. This results in a stroboscopic effect where the LEDs appear to blink or flicker.

Here‚Äôs a more detailed explanation:

  • Pulse Width Modulation (PWM):

LED lights often use PWM to control their brightness by rapidly switching the LED on and off.

  • Frequency Mismatch:

If the frequency at which the LEDs are switching on and off (the PWM frequency) doesn‚Äôt align with the dashcam‚Äôs frame rate and shutter speed, the stroboscopic effect can make the lights appear to flicker.

  • Example:

If the LED light is switching on and off at 60 Hz, but the camera is recording at 30 FPS, the dashcam might capture the LED as flickering.
=========End Google AI==========

Now - I can‚Äôt say for certain how this will effect your vision. So far, it isn‚Äôt significant enough to throw ours off.
